name: Maya Chen
description: Maya is a 31-year-old data analyst in Portland, OR, renting a one-bedroom with her partner and a rescue dog. Motivated by rising rents and the desire for stability, she aims to buy within 6–9 months. She’s targeting a 2-bedroom condo or small townhome with good natural light, a small outdoor space, and a dedicated home office. Walkability, bike lanes, nearby parks, and access to transit matter as much as commute time. Financially disciplined, Maya has a mid-700s credit score and is saving toward a 10–15% down payment. She’s comparing conventional, FHA, and local first-time buyer programs, and uses spreadsheets to model PITI, HOA fees, taxes, and maintenance. Her budget guardrails keep housing costs under 28% of gross income and total DTI under 36%. Maya is data-driven but values the “feel” of a space. She prefers agents who are transparent, hates high-pressure tactics, and is comfortable with cosmetic updates but avoids structural risk. She gets pre-approved with multiple lenders, scrutinizes Loan Estimates, and considers points or temporary buydowns if seller credits are available. Key anxieties include bidding wars, appraisal gaps, and surprise repairs; she mitigates them with thorough inspections, contingencies, and a strong emergency fund. Sustainability, energy efficiency, and resale potential are pluses.
example_behaviours: Spends Sunday mornings touring open houses with a coffee and logging pros/cons in a Notion board.
Sets up saved searches and rate alerts on Zillow/Redfin; color-codes listings by must-haves and deal-breakers.
Maintains a mortgage spreadsheet modeling PITI at varying rates, down payments, and HOA scenarios.
Attends first-time buyer webinars and local credit-union workshops to compare programs and down payment assistance.
Requests pre-approvals from two to three lenders and compares APR, points, and lender credits line by line.
Carries a laser measure and outlet tester to showings; photographs labels on electrical panels and appliances.
Reads HOA meeting minutes and budgets to spot special assessments or low reserves.
Bikes or drives through target neighborhoods at different times to check noise, parking, and safety.
Creates Pinterest mood boards for light, low-cost updates; browses Habitat ReStore and Facebook Marketplace for materials.
Tracks interest-rate news and considers a lock strategy around major Fed announcements.
Volunteers at a community garden; is a houseplant enthusiast who values south-facing light.
Hosts potluck dinners and tests kitchen workflow during showings by imagining traffic flow and storage.
